results.title: Foods and nutrition
results.brief_description: A study of the metabolic processes of the body, illustrated by animated diagrams showing the distribution of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, minerals, and vitamins, and by experiments carried out on white mice.

results.title: Food preservation
results.creator_credit: Hugh Hudson, Cammell Hudson and Unilever Films
results.brief_description: Discusses modern developments in food preservation, including quick-freezing and canning. Also shows by animation and microphotography the growth and decay of cells, and the effect of bacterial action in the cell breakdown.

results.title: Food or famine
results.creator_credit: Alvin Bailey, Martha Varley, Stuart Legg and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: One-half of the human population is either underfed or malnourished; every year 50 million mouths are added to the world’s population, yet only one-tenth of the earth’s surface is farmed. Food production must be increased by using improved strains of crops, chemicals, land reclamation and better methods of fishing, plus research into hydroponics - growing crops in water with the necessary chemicals added which are present naturally in the soil.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alvin Bailey, Martha Varley, Stuart Legg and Shell Film Unit

results.creator_credit: Kathleen O'Brien and New Zealand National Film Unit

results.title: Food from the reluctant earth
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Lesley Hammond and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the cereal belt area of South Australia, where farmers must grow crops without irrigation and maintain livestock with a minimum of water. Explains the wheat/legume rotation system that enables farmers to obtain high yields.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edwin Scragg, Lesley Hammond and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Food for thought
results.creator_credit: T.A. Abraham, K Khandpur, Indian Film Unit and UNICEF
results.brief_description: This prize-winning film illustrates the problems of the rural community of Orissa as it strives to combat hunger and malnutrition by use of improved methods of poultry and fish farming, cultivation of school gardens and nutrition education.

results.title: Food and people
results.brief_description: Draws a contrast between people who have plenty to eat and those who have next to nothing. Followers of Thomas Malthus are convinced that a world of plenty will never be possible; others believe the world’s population should be limited; and another group advocates the increase of food production and distribution. The latter concept also stresses conservation of resources and improved agricultural methods. Emphasises that with free world trade, peoples of all nations will benefit. Suggests that a world of plenty provides greater chances for individual security and world peace.

results.title: Following the plough
results.creator_credit: Filmwest Associates and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A tour of contemporary Canadian agriculture led by a modern troubador whose work on the land moves him to song. What is seen is farming as big business coast-to-coast, mechanised, automated, where the farmer is businessman, scientist, world citizen, but still a man with a desire for independence and his own place on the land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Filmwest Associates and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Chemical reactions II
results.creator_credit: Barrie Whatley, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Demonstrates a series of chemical reactions designed to show that the course of the reaction can be followed by measuring various parameters. One reaction shown is that between tertiary butyl bromide and water, and rates are observed by measuring the volume of a gas evolved, the ph change, change of boiling point, and changes in light absorption during reactions.
